<br/>
<br/>

<p>Empower Your Plate; Know Your Food; Uncover the Truth of Foods when you shop using <a target="_blank" href="https://mungo-meal.onrender.com/">Mungo Meal</a>!
  Users can see and save detailed nutritional information on their favorite foods in a digestible way when shopping to make healthy and informed decisions. 
  Users won't have to guess what they're placing into their cart or putting into their mouths and can spot dishonest claims and labels.
</p>

## How It's Made:

**Featured Tech:**

<p></p>
<p>Mungo Meal has OpenFoodFacts API integration to get up-to-date information about all the products you need.</p>

## Mungo Meal has updated to version 1.0.0!
Users can sign up for a free Mungo Meal account to track what's in their food and build their smart shopping cart.

## For Demo Use:

Demo Email: <span>mungomeal@</span><span>mail.com</span>

Demo Password: mungomeal

## Next Version
In the upcoming v1.1, more features will be added to improve accessibility and customizability. This new version would bring the addition of:
- Pagination to views
- Comparing Similar Products with a score
- Users to add custom food items.

## Next features to implement:
- Adding a status indicator for the FoodFactsAPI that lets you know whether it's offline.
- Adding image quality settings when searching by description for items
- Adding settings to modify how many results you want to appear per page
- Integrate a serving size calculator that scales the results with your desired portions.

### Possible future updates
- Create daily values percent (%dv) for micro and macronutrients and existing amounts per serving.
- Make a user allergen warning system that alerts users when foods may contain what they're allergic to.
- Add vegan product filtering, and alert users when a product may contain meat/dairy/eggs.
- Cumulate all the detailed information for each product into a meal plan, and compare new options / better alternatives for other products.

## Lessons Learned:

<p>While many of the components themselves were not too state-reliant, User information has to be accessed by many components from many pages, which useContext/createContext is ideal for. 
  Good practices, such as knowing when to raise the state or implement co-location, aid in making this process less complicated.</p>

<p>Using an SQL database (PostgreSQL through Supabase), which is often touted as the most reliable and battle-tested way to host a DB was greatly to my benefit.
While no direct SQL was specifically used in this task due to the Supabase API interaction, I often started planning the process by writing out SQL queries first.
Compared to more contemporary solutions (i.e. MongoDB, with NoSQL document database), the process of going through data normalization within a relational database is an efficient way to work with structured data with set fields and records.</p>

<p>Using react-router-dom to build together a single-paged application allowed me to enhance the UX while preserving the HTML5 History API to keep track of where a user is letting them backtrack and press the back button was awesome.</p>

<p>The more functionality you have on a site that works without signing up, the better the experience for the user. In this app, only the favorites functionality is restricted behind logging in. 
That allows people to try the app first, love it, and then want to save their favorite items in their cart.</p>

<p>As always, reading documentation is the most effective way to learn how to personalize the tools I use and bring the most out of them.</p>
